Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships to Aid Rio Hondo STEM Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With an NSF S-STEM award, Rio Hondo College is annually supporting approximately 21 academically talented and financially needy STEM students through the "Scholarships to Aid Rio Hondo STEM Students"(STARRS) program. By reducing financial barriers, the college is augmenting retention and increasing persistence through several proven techniques.

STARRS scholars are attending full-time, working less hours at jobs, meeting regularly with faculty mentors, and participating in the college's Math, Engineering, and Science Achievement (MESA) and/or TRiO Student Support Services STEM (SSS) programs. These students have access to the MESA Center and careful advising to support their personal educational plans. In addition they have priority registration to implement a clustering into the same sections of mathematics and science courses, regular contact with the MESA/SSS STEM Director and the Educational Advisor, financial literacy education, and support for additional scholarship and internship applications.

STARRS students are encouraged to attend Academic Excellence Workshops led by student-peer facilitators to help them excel in mathematics, physics and chemistry courses, and they can utilize drop-in tutoring in mathematics, physics, chemistry and biology in the MESA Center. One-on-one tutoring is freely available for students who are identified by an early alert system. S-STEM scholars may attend transfer conferences, tours of four-year colleges, universities, and local industry employers, and they are eligible to apply for all-expenses-paid travel to meetings of professional societies.

This program has the innovative feature that scholarship amounts are determined by the number of science and mathematics courses in which the student enrolls during the next academic year. Applicants must show residency, be a STEM major, show financial need, demonstrate academic merit, and submit an essay describing academic goals and how the scholarship will enable them to reduce the number of work hours. Results from these innovative scholarship features are being disseminated through conferences and the college's website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scholarships To Aid Rio Hondo STEM Students (STARSS), Rio Hondo College’s was funded through the National Science Foundation’s Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM). With these funds, the college provided scholarships to academically talented, but financially needy students working to transfer to a four-year institution to complete an undergraduate degree in a science, technology, engineering, or math major. The college’s objective was to expand and retain the STEM talent pool and increase the number of STEM majors.

 

One hundred and twenty students were awarded nearly $600,000. Of these, thirty-five were supported in their first year of study at their transfer institution. The amount that each student received was based on the number of transfer-level mathematics and science courses they were enrolled in, from $4,000 for two courses per semester to $6000 for six in the academic year. Students who successfully completed the major preparation and were accepted to a university received $6,000. The purpose of awarding these amounts was to relieve our students of the pressure of having to work. The Rio Hondo College student population consists of 66% low-income and 86% from underrepresented groups.

 

STARSS Scholars had access to the services and activities of the Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement (MESA) program. Services include detailed advising, priority registration, financial literacy workshops, early alert reviews, and assistance with fellowship and internship applications. Students were expected to attend peer-led Academic Excellence Workshops and when needed, to use drop-in tutoring. They were eligible to attend transfer conferences and college and industry tours with the MESA program. Furthermore, they were required to attend the weekly MESA Hour, a seminar focused on study skills, time management, and pre-professional development. The final piece of the STARRS program was the mentoring each student received from a STEM faculty member.
